By other spells, Melusine erected the great Castle Lusignan, where she and Raymond made their home.</p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'> 美人鱼传说 I </font></p> <br/><p align='left'>雷曼骑士与普瓦提埃伯爵是好朋友。有一次他们相约狩猎野猪，但普瓦提埃伯爵被发怒的野猪袭击了，摔下马来。勇敢的雷曼冲过来，拯救他的朋友，试图杀掉这头丧心病狂的野兽，但他的剑击偏了，没能杀掉那头野兽，反而将他的朋友杀死了。对自己铸下的大错懊悔不已，雷曼逃进了森林深处，在那里为自己的朋友哀悼不已。他不知道自己所做的一切都在一段古老的邪恶预言之中。口渴万分，他跪倒在林中的一处潭边，喝了一口水，歇息了一阵。突然，他看到了一位绝美的少女坐在潭边。她立刻向他走过来，问他，一位骑士会在这深山老林之中寻觅着什么呢，又是为什么，他会如此悲伤。为她的美貌所折服，雷曼对这个少女一见钟情，将他所经历的一切不幸尽数向她倾诉。倾诉之后，他当即向她求婚，而这位名叫梅露西娜的少女，接受了他的求婚，但同时她警告他，她的丈夫不能在星期六进入她的房间，而且必须整日让她一个人独处。 <br/> <br/> 这位骑士便带着他的未婚妻离开了森林，自那一刻起，他便好运连连。他击败了家族内所有的旧敌，将他们绳之以法，并且夺回了许多别人从他那荣耀的家族手中夺走的城堡与领地。他和他的家族因此美名远扬。雷曼英勇无畏地追随领主，领主问他想要什么回报。骑士于是便回答，他想要一张牡鹿皮那么大的土地作为自由支配的领地。他的领主笑着答应了，不知道是梅露西娜让骑士找来一块鹿皮，切成带状，然后做成一条绳子。她用魔咒让这条绳子变得更长了，这样它便可以圈住更多的土地。梅露西娜在这块土地之中变出了一口泉水来灌溉土地，以确保每年都有很好的收成。通过施展其他的魔法，梅露西娜又建起了鲁西格南城堡，这座城堡便成为了她和雷曼的家。 </p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'>The Tale of Melusine II</font></p> <br/><p align='left'>Knight Raymond and Melusine lived happily and had many children together, all of whom were marked by the mark of the family, though all became brave knights and wise rulers. In time, though, Raymond began to be consumed by curiosity as to what his wife was doing alone in her chambers on Saturday and why only she could be there on that day. So one Saturday he hid and waited for his wife to come to her chambers. With his knife he cut a slit in the door through which he could see inside. And what he spied there horrified him. In the room was a big tub of water in which Melusine reclined, but from the waist down she had the body of a scaly creature – a serpent! Fright gripped his heart and he called out in surprise. At which Melusine realised that her husband had betrayed him promise to her. She was seized by terrible sadness, turned into a dragon and flew out the window. And from that moment Raymond never saw his wife again… <br/> <br/>Until, many, many years later, she appeared to him to tell him he would die in three days time. And so it came to pass, and Raymond died. From that day forth cursed Melusine secretly guards the lives of all the descendants of her line, and appears to them three days before their death to foretell it. <br/> <br/>As was foretold, many glorious princely families descended from the line of Raymond and Melusine. Among the most renowned, respected and foremost of them is the Luxembourg family, including Wenceslas IV, King of Bohemia, and his brother Sigismund, King of Hungary. That is why the knights of this clan often carry in tournaments an ornament in the form of a dragon, and because they themselves have a little dragon’s blood in them, it is not prudent to anger them or enter into conflict with them or disagree with them, because their lineage makes them quick-tempered, quarrelsome and hot-blooded.</p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'> 美人鱼传说 II </font></p> <br/><p align='left'>骑士雷曼和梅露西娜从此幸福地生活在了一起，生了许多孩子。他们全都继承了家族的象征，变成了勇敢的骑士和英明的统治者。可是，渐渐地，雷曼开始好奇他的妻子星期六一个人在屋子里到底在做什么，以及为什么非得她要在那一天独处。所以在一个星期六，他躲起来，等着她的妻子进入了她的房间。之后用一把小刀在门上开了个小孔，这样他便可以看到里面发生了什么。他窥视到了触目惊心的一幕。房间里有一个盛满水的大水缸，梅露西娜就在里面躺着，但她的下身被鳞片所覆盖了-一条大蛇！他吓得叫出声来，梅露西娜意识到她的丈夫背叛了当初对她许下的承诺。她伤心至极，变成了一条龙，从窗户飞走了。自那以后，雷曼便再没见过他的爱人…… <br/> <br/>直到，很多，很多年以后，她来到他的身边，告诉他，他所剩的生命只有三天。三天的时间，转瞬即逝，雷曼便永远地闭上了眼睛。从那时起，被诅咒的梅露西娜便秘密地守护着她的家族的后人，在他们逝世三天前，出现在他们身边，将这件事告诉他们。 <br/> <br/>相传，很多称霸一方的荣耀的家族都是雷曼和梅露西娜的后人。最有名的，最有威望的，位列群雄之首的就是卢森堡家族，包括波西米亚国王，瓦茨拉夫四世，以及他的表兄，匈牙利王，西格斯蒙德。因为这个传说的缘故，骑士竞技时的装备常有龙的装饰，而且由于他们自认为身体里流淌着龙的血，招惹他们，与他们发起冲突，还是与他们立场相对，都是不明智的，因为他们的血统使他们变得易怒、狂暴、热血。 </p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'>The New Council by Smil Flashka of Pardubice</font></p> <br/><p align='left'>‘Twas in a time that’s now long gone, <br/>The King of all the beasts, the lion, <br/>Sent his envoys far and near<br/>For all the animals to hear. <br/>Every one, both great and small, <br/>Must answer to their monarch’s call. <br/> <br/>This command the lion did say; <br/>Even Prince Eagle must obey <br/>And bring all birds upon the wing, <br/>To come and bow before their king. <br/>The king’s command by all was heard, <br/>They heeded well the royal word. <br/>Even the eagle’s princely domain<br/>Could not deny the lion’s reign. <br/>It too was subject to the king, <br/>Who in those days ruled everything. <br/> <br/>And so the eagle, Prince of birds, <br/>Obeyed the lion’s royal words<br/>And brought his legions of the air. <br/>All creatures then assembled there<br/>In one great restless throng awaiting<br/>Anxious to oblige their great king. <br/>Attentively they craned their necks, <br/>To hear what orders would come next. <br/> <br/>Looking down on all his court, <br/>The lion started to report<br/>Why they were all assembled here<br/>To hear his words with pricked-up ears: <br/>“Loyal subjects, dearest friends, <br/>Well I know that to the end<br/>You served my father faithfully, <br/>As all know well on land and sea, <br/>‘Twas by your council and your aid, <br/>His kingdom of the world he made. <br/> <br/>This loyalty shall you give me too, <br/>For I have placed my trust in you, <br/>Lords and ladies, princes, knights, <br/>Subjects of my realm by rights. <br/>I am a king of tender years, <br/>And so you all are gathered here, <br/>To advise me, each and every one, <br/>How my dominion should be run.” <br/>........................................................ <br/> <br/> (Continues with how the animals advised their king to rule wisely and justly, so that his kingdom would prosper and his subjects thrive. All of this, though, is treated of in another book.)</p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'> 帕杜比采的史麦尔·弗拉什卡的新议会 </font></p> <br/><p align='left'>很久很久以前， <br/>百兽之王，狮子， <br/>派遣他的信使到各地 <br/>宣告万物。 <br/>所有动物，无论大小，<br/>都要响应国王的号召。 <br/> <br/>狮子颁布如下圣旨： <br/>就算鹰王也要遵从 <br/>用翅膀带领诸多鸟雀， <br/>前来觐见便跪拜国王。 <br/>百兽响应王的召唤， <br/>纷纷遵从皇上旨意。 <br/>就算鹰王骄横跋扈 <br/>也无法匹敌狮子的威严。 <br/>他也得向国王低头， <br/>普天之下，莫非王土。 <br/> <br/>于是雄鹰，群鸟之王， <br/>遵从了狮子的旨意 <br/>带领他的空中军团前去上朝。 <br/>百兽就在朝廷集结 <br/>迫不及待地等着 <br/>按耐不住要为国王效命的心情。 <br/>他们伸长了脖子， <br/>翘首着下一道命令的颁布。 <br/> <br/>巡视满朝文武， <br/>狮子开始宣布 <br/>为什么叫诸位在这里集结 <br/>仔细倾听他所要说的话： <br/>“忠诚的臣子们，诸位亲朋好友， <br/>我对此深信不疑 <br/>你们为我的父辈效命， <br/>上刀山，下火海，在所不辞。 <br/>也是由于你们的议会，你们的帮助， <br/>他才能建立如此功业。 <br/> <br/>你们也要对我这般忠心不二， <br/>我已将信任寄托在了你们身上， <br/>诸位领主和夫人，诸位王侯和骑士， <br/>所有领土之内的臣民们。 <br/>身为国王，我资历尚浅， <br/>因此我把列位召集至此， <br/>来向我进谏，每位都要提出意见。 <br/>告诉我如何才能治理好我的国土。” <br/>........................................................ <br/> <br/> （接下来有关于动物们向国王进谏，如何英明公正地治理，使它的国家繁荣昌盛，它的子民安居乐业的记述。但是，这些记述，都保存在另一本书里。） </p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'>On the Adamites or Naked Worshippers</font></p> <br/><p align='left'> In the year of our Lord 1259 a new heretical sect did come to Bohemia and settled amongst the people. The Adamites, or naturists, travelled through the land at that time. Exposing their backs, they did roll as pigs in mud and beat themselves with canes and then through the land did proceed with their nakedness and shame for all to see. They spake evil of our fatherly pastors and of the word of God when they proclaimed that “our devotion to God and our atonement be of greater worth than your praying”. And they did press for the Holy Mass to be done away with, for it was their belief that every soul could find its way towards the Heavenly Father without the Holy Church’s guidance. And when the common people and lords alike did see this, for they were ignorant of the knowledge that it was the Devil’s hands that led the Adamites, they did join unto them and in great numbers their backs did beat. Even the women did avow themselves to these unclean deeds! Had they the desire to make their lives right with God and atonement therein receive, they should have turned to the priests. But lo! The naturists, guided by the devil Lucifer, did endeavour to replace the Holy Pope on his throne! When this news was heard in the holy city of Rome, an army was raised to smite these heretics by sword and by flame. For they were indeed nothing more than heretics.</p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'> 《阿达米亚裸身教徒》 </font></p> <br/><p align='left'> 公元1259年，新的一支异教徒来到了波西米亚，在人们之间居住下来。这些异教徒被称作阿达米亚人，或者裸身主义者，没有固定的居所。他们赤裸着后背，在泥潭里像猪一样打滚，用藤条鞭挞着自己，不停流浪，甘愿将他们的裸体与屈辱展示给所有人看。他们污蔑我们神圣的牧师，甚至是上帝的诫命。他们叫嚣：“我们对上帝的奉献，以及我们的救赎，将比你们的祈祷要尊贵太多了。”他们还要求撤销弥撒圣祭，因为他们相信没有神圣教会的引到，每个生灵都能独自找到上天堂的方法。当民众与领主看到异教徒的到来，由于不知道阿达米亚乃恶魔的信徒，他们竟加入了异教徒的行列，而且鞭挞起自己的后背来。连女人们都声称要做这种龌龊的勾当！如果他们希望遵从上帝的指引，希望获得救赎，他们应当去追随牧师。但是，看啊！这群裸身主义者，恶魔路西法的使徒，竟然妄图篡夺神圣的教皇之位！这个消息传到圣城罗马之后，一支大军便前来讨伐这群异教徒，以刀剑与烈火粉碎了他们的野心。这群人的出现毫无价值，只是一群顽固不化的异教徒在虚张声势而已。 </p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'>On Libusse and Premysl</font></p> <br/><p align='left'> Krok, ruler of the Bohemian tribes, had been blessed with three daughters. Kazi, Teta, and Libusse. Kazi possessed vast knowledge of all matter of flora and herbs and was wise in the arts of healing, Teta above all others worshipped the gods and goddesses and made unto them all manner of sacrifices, and the last daughter enjoyed great favour and respect, for wisdom and reason did serve her well, and having been endowed with the power of soothsaying, oft did look into the future and make prophesies. When old Krok died, it was she who sat upon the throne and ruled wisely, for she could resolve conflict with her esteemed reasoning and bring peace to all aggrieved parties.<br/> <br/> It was a time of abundance and equality between all; however, her rule went against the will of many men, for as is told "long of hair and short of reason, and shame be upon men who are ruled by a woman." Libusse, suffering great pangs of sorrow, convened a great congress to which she did invite her sisters and the elder rulers from throughout the land. And she did say unto them, "You do not appreciate freedom and for you it is a great shame for a woman to rule over you. Thus, I shall give unto you a Voivode—a man—upon condition that you listen to my words and heed my advice.” <br/> <br/> The joyous rulers from throughout the land did swear to heed her words, and she did order them to place saddle upon her steed and allow him to go whither he may roam. At this place shall they lay eyes upon their new Voivode, a ploughman, who shall be driving a team of oxen. And it did happen as she had foreseen, and the horse did truly lead them to the ploughman, who bore the name of Přemysl. They said unto him, “Princess Libusse and all of the people of the great Czech hereby do entreat you to come with us and accept the rule that fate has bestowed upon you and your descendants.” And in reply to the messengers Přemysl did say, “It is regrettable that you have come this very morning. For if I could finish ploughing this one field, bread would be had in great abundance for all time. But alas, you have disturbed me in my task and this land shall oft know great hunger.” And then he said unto them, “I shall repeat the words that Libusse has said unto you. As you did not desire to heed a girl’s advice, now it shall be my lineage that rules over you with an iron rod.” Thereafter, he travelled with them to Libusse, whose fair hand he took in marriage, and for many years ruled wisely and well. After him his sons ruled in his stead, and thus was established the great and esteemed Přemyslid Dynasty.</p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'>《丽波瑟与普莱米索》 </font></p> <br/><p align='left'> 克劳克，波西米亚部落的首领，育有三女。卡紫，蒂塔，和丽波瑟。卡紫通晓花草及医术，蒂塔创立了为众神献祭的传统，而小女儿则最受爱戴，由于她学识渊博，又拥有占卜之神力，可预言未来。克劳克仙逝后，便是她执掌大权，治理英明，以超人的智慧解决了内部矛盾，安抚了忿忿不平的部族。 <br/> <br/> 那时虽然国泰民安，但她的统治仍受到不少阻碍，因上有古训：“长发短智，对女子俯首称臣，乃男人之耻辱。”悲伤失落的丽波瑟召集了一场大会，会上请到了她的姐姐，以及领土各地的长老首领。她向他们宣布：“既然你们不愿拥有自由，既然你们觉得对女人俯首称臣乃是耻辱，那好，我就给你们找来一位族长-一个男族长-条件是，你们必须要服从我的管理与领导。” <br/> <br/> 满意的各路领主宣誓接受她的条件，她随即便命人放了自己的坐骑，任它四处奔走。众人翘首以待新族长，一个与牛羊为伍的农夫的到来。正如她所预言的那样，她的坐骑确实把众人的目光引到了这位名叫“普莱米索”的农夫身上。众人便告知他：“丽波瑟女王，暨全体捷克人民，恭候您的驾临，接受您与您后代的治理。”普莱米索这样回复信使：“你们来的太早了。如果我能犁完这片地，总有面包招待诸位。但是，唉，倘若你们打断了我的劳作，这片土地可就要经受饥饿之苦了。”而他又对他们说：“我会谨遵丽波瑟的意愿行事。既然你们不愿服从一个女子的命令，现在就由我来对你们发号施令，严加治理。”随后，他便随使者回见丽波瑟，与她喜结连理，一同英明地治国许多年。他去世后，膝下之子继承父业，建立了伟大而尊贵的普莱米索王朝。</p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'>On Old Father Czech</font></p> <br/><p align='left'> Many centuries ere it came to be that a Voivode Czech lived in the distant lands of the Croats. Bethinking the great lack of land for his people, he resolved to set forth from his native country. Therewith convening a large congress, he made offerings to the gods, parted ways with the beloved country of his birth, and set off towards the West in search of new lands. Women, children, the elderly--on foot and in wagon, their livestock and property in tow--the entire nation followed its great leader. It was many weeks hence they reached a new country, one hitherto unknown. But lo! The people of this land spoke in a tongue that was not deaf to their ears. And they persevered, proceeding farther, until they reached a place where the inhabitants were dressed only in fur and of a hirsute appearance and blocked their path with arms in their hands. And thus they continued onward, deep through dense, untamed forests, through swamp and brush, until they came to a mountain called Říp, which rose imposingly above the surrounding plain. The entire nation, being fatigued by the exertion of its great journey, dispersed and surrounded the mountain, for to regain their strength.<br/> <br/> Therewith Czech himself ascended the mountain, surveying the land from its heights. He beheld fertile lowlands and forests, a wealth of waters and green grazing land. On the morn, with him ascended the mountain a great abundance of his people, and upon beholding that which he too had seen, their hearts sang out. Thus spoke Voivode Czech: "Henceforth we shall not be in want, for we have found the land that we once sought! Behold! This is the promised land, one of milk and honey, pregnant with beasts of the hunt. Here we shall find great abundance and here shall we find protection from our enemy. But it lacks a name. What say you? How shall we call this great place?" In response, all stood as one and let it heard out in a unison of voices, "May it share your name!" And to the ground they did fall, kissing the soil of their new country, which has henceforth borne the name of Czech. </p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'> 《捷克人的祖先》 </font></p> <br/><p align='left'> 许多世纪以来，一位名叫捷克的族长居住在遥远的克罗地亚。由于看到他的民众缺少耕地，他便决定从他的祖国出发远征。随后召开了一场大会，会上他向诸神献祭，离开了生养他的祖国，向西进发，寻找新的土地。妇孺，老人-赤足行走，或是乘坐马车，拖家带口-整个国家追随着他们伟大的领袖。几周后，他们抵达了一个全新的国度，那个国度的名字却无人知晓。但是，看啊！这片新大陆上的人民居然说着他们的语言。接着，他们继续冒险，向远方进发，又到了一个地方，那里的住民只穿皮毛，而且毛发很重，拿着武器，拦住了捷克族人的去路。历经万险，他们继续前进，穿越茂密的原始森林，跨过沼泽与荆棘，终于到达了在平原上高耸凸起的瑞普山下。整个国家的民众都已为艰辛的征途感到劳累，于是便在山的周围暂居下来，以重拾前行的力量。 <br/> <br/> 捷克独自登上山顶，四周的景色一览无余。他看到了富饶的低地与森林，丰富的水源与碧绿的牧场。黎明时分，众人追随他一同来到山顶，看到了他所惊叹的景色，众人心花怒放。捷克族长随即宣布：“得此一地，我们别无所求！看啊！这便是我们的应许之地，充盈着乳汁与蜜饯，孕育着珍禽与异兽。此地资源富饶，亦是易守难攻。只是它尚未命名。敢问诸位有何见教？此富饶之地，该当如何称谓？” 众人回应如潮，却不约而同：“就以您的名字为此地命名！”随后，他们跪下亲吻新家园的土地，从此，这片土地便有了个伟大的名字：捷克。</p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'>On Saint Procopius</font></p> <br/><p align='left'> Abbot Procopius, a good Czech of outstanding learning, was first an earthly priest, who led an honourable life in full devotion to God. Later, when much blood had been spilt in the Kingdom of Bohemia, he went into reclusion, far away from people, to be disturbed by no man and far from all that is earthly and impure and to find isolation and peace so that he could pray to God. With great passion in his heart, he denied his wife and his home, his worldly property, his relatives and friends, and lo, even his own self did he deny, subjecting himself to God’s will alone. Fleeing from the tempest of human society and full of love for Christ, he left for the wilderness and there he settled, under the arches of an abandoned cave, whither armed with but the armor of his faith and the swords of the heavens did he drive forth the demons that had ere lived at that place. For many years did he dwell in the cave, his virtues shielding him from all temptation and impropriety. Prayer, fasting, and keeping vigil bound him fast to the firm rock that is Christ.<br/> <br/> Through the mercy of the heavens did tales of the most holy Procopius’s virtues spread so that people from all corners of the Earth began to seek him out. This clean, pure, and prudent man did listen to their pleas and confessions and thus their hearts were turned to faith and their thoughts corrected. From the many gifts that were brought to him, he then built a monastery over his cave and for the greater glory of the Virgin Mary and Saint John the Baptist he called forth a gathering of several most pious brothers in Christ. Alongside his brethren, he pursued a pious life of strict morals and, using the rule of the good Father Benedict as a model, for them he did establish monastic rules for worshiping God.<br/> <br/> Later, when Procopius had died and his soul had entered into heaven a saint and his body in his cave did lie, the monastery received his name and thereafter it has borne the title the Benedictine Monastery of Saint Procopius.</p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'> 《圣普罗科匹厄斯》 </font></p> <br/><p align='left'> 修道院院长，普罗科匹厄斯，一位学识渊博的捷克人，乃是尘世间第一位将一生完全奉献给上帝的牧师。晚年时，波西米亚战乱频繁，他选择隐居荒野，远离人世，以及人世间一切不洁的世俗之争，通过找到绝对的隔绝与安宁，全心全意地向上帝祈祷。一颗狂热的虔诚之心，使他离开了他的夫人和家庭，以及他所有的财产，亲朋好友，看啊，他甚至批判着自己世俗的身体，只想遵循上帝的指引。从世俗中脱身而出，对基督无限爱戴的他，远走荒野，在一处废弃洞穴深处隐居起来。武装他的不是铠甲，而是他的信念。他用天国的刀剑驱赶了所有世俗世界纠缠着他的魔鬼。他在洞穴里居住了多年，他的美德抵御了所有的诱惑及错误。祈祷，斋戒，守着基督的信仰，有如守着坚硬的磐石。 <br/> <br/> 上天也为此感动，使无上圣洁的普罗科匹厄斯的美德传遍了整片国土，人们开始四处寻找他。这位纯净，圣洁，慎独之人倾听他们的祈求与忏悔，劝说他们回心转意，引他们走上正道。他将所有人们带给他的礼物攒起来，在他所居住的山洞处建起了一座修道院，献给尊贵的圣母玛丽，以及施洗者圣约翰，随后召集起了一群最虔诚的基督教修士。与他的修士兄弟们一起，以严格的信仰道德要求自己，以圣本笃的教条为准则，创设了一套修道院的行为准则，更虔诚地追随上帝。 <br/> <br/> 后来，普罗科匹厄斯仙逝以后，他的灵魂升到了天堂，成为了一位圣人。而在他逝世的洞穴，修道院便以他的名字命名，遂叫做：圣普罗科匹厄斯的本笃教团修道院。 </p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'>On Saint Wenceslas</font></p> <br/><p align='left'> In Bohemia there was a prince of the name Vratislaus and his wife was Drahomira. Unto them was born a son and they gave unto him the name of Wenceslas. After his father’s untimely death, he was to sit upon the throne, but having yet been grown of age, his mother ruled the land in his stead and it was his grandmother Ludmila who cared for his upbringing. His brother was Boleslaus and they grew up together, although they had little in common. Through God’s mercy, Wenceslas learned to read and write. Being learned of books and firm of faith, he could wield a sword as well. But above all it was peace and his country that he did love. He performed many kind acts unto the poor, clothing the naked and feeding the hungry, protecting the servants of God and having many churches erected. He was a paragon for his people and a ruler that was kind above others, for with his enemies he always did negotiate with good intentions and they too did kneel before his piety. With his whole heart he exalted God and the good deeds he performed were innumerable.<br/> <br/> Thus, it was to the surprise of none that the Devil planted the seed of hatred in many corrupted men’s hearts and set them against Wenceslas. He urged them, like so many Judases, to revolt against their lord and then they did whisper to Boleslaus that his brother wished to take his life. Boleslaus, believing these words, devised a plan, out of fear and resentment, to take his brother Wenceslas’s throne as well as his life.<br/> <br/> He knew that whenever a new church was consecrated, Wenceslas would go to that place to pray. And he did thusly when on Sunday on the Feast of Saints Cosmas and Damian he entered Boleslaus’s castle and having attended mass, he prepared to depart for Prague. His brother, detaining him, invited him to the table to drink, but Wenceslas declined. Early in the morning, Wenceslas rose and hurried to morning mass. When in front of the church gate he met his brother he said unto him “Brother, last evening you served us well.” Boleslaus then, guided by the Devil, responded thusly: “And now I shall serve you even better” and as those words left his mouth, he struck Wenceslas a blow to the head with his sword. And Boleslaus’s dogs set upon him as well and together with their master, they killed Wenceslas and left his broken body in front of the church. Boleslaus then sat upon his brother’s throne.<br/> <br/> Today Wenceslas has already been sainted and established to be the patron saint of the lands of Bohemia. Well call unto him in times of darkness and to him we pray: “Saint Wenceslas, patron saint of our country, pray for us!”</p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'> 《圣瓦茨拉夫》 </font></p> <br/><p align='left'> 波西米亚有为名叫夫拉提斯雷的国王，他的夫人名叫德雷霍米拉。他们生养一子，取名瓦茨拉夫。夫拉提斯雷逝世后，其子瓦茨拉夫继承了王位，但因尚未成年，由母后摄政，而他则由祖母卢德米拉继续抚养。他的弟弟名叫波尔斯劳斯，兄弟二人从小如影随形，却鲜有共同之处。上帝有恩，瓦茨拉夫学会了读写。饱读群书，信仰坚定的他，也练就了超群的剑术。但他所真正热爱的是和平与他的家园。他乐善好施，帮助了许多穷人，穿不起衣裳的，就给予他们衣着，吃不起东西的，就给予他们食物，同时保护上帝的仆人，建起了许多教堂。他既是人民的榜样，又是一位德高望重的仁君。与对手沟通时，总是以德服人，令对手敬佩他的睿诚。他全心全意地侍奉上帝，做了无数好事。 <br/> <br/> 只是，魔鬼常会在堕落之人的心里埋下仇恨的种子，这一次，他把矛头指向了瓦茨拉夫。他教唆那群堕落之人，就像曾经他教唆犹大那般，煽动他们背叛他们的国王。堕落之人便秘密地告诉波尔斯劳斯，他的哥哥要取他的性命。波尔斯劳斯听信了奸人的谗言，恐惧恼怒之中下定决心，计划要杀了哥哥瓦茨拉夫，顺便篡夺王位。 <br/> <br/> 他知道一旦有新的教堂竣工，瓦茨拉夫必会前去祈祷。不出所料，瓦茨拉夫在礼拜日出席祭奠圣徒科斯马斯与达米安的集会，来到了波尔斯劳斯的城堡，弥撒结束后，准备返回布拉格。而他的弟弟却百般挽留，邀请他喝酒，但被瓦茨拉夫拒绝了。一大早，瓦茨拉夫赶去参加弥撒。在教堂大门前，他被弟弟拦了下来。他对弟弟说：“弟弟，昨晚你待我们不薄。”之后，已被魔鬼所控制的波尔斯劳斯答道：“现在我要再给你一份大礼。”话音未落，他便一剑刺中了瓦茨拉夫的头部。波尔斯劳斯身边的猎犬早就按耐不住，它和主人一同撕碎了瓦茨拉夫的尸体，将他的石块扔在了教堂门口，之后扬长而去。波尔斯劳斯随即接过了兄长的皇位。 <br/> <br/> 如今，瓦茨拉夫已被尊为圣人，成为了波西米亚大陆的守护神。暗无天日之时，我们便向他祈祷：“圣瓦茨拉夫，王国的守护神，请为我们祈祷！” </p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'>On Saint Adalbert</font></p> <br/><p align='left'> Upon the death of Bishop Dietmar, the first Bishop of the Kingdom of Bohemia, Voitek, known as Adalbert, of the Slavnik clan, took his place. It transpired in the year 982. Recalling to mind the words of his predecessor, that amongst the common people many injustices had spread, that polygamy amongst the nobility and blood feuds amongst the people did flourish, that no soul did honour neither Sabbath nor holy days and in their place they held markets, that Christians were sold into slavery, and that in the countryside pagan customs did flourish, he resolved to devote his life to fighting against such iniquity. For five years did he endeavour to eradicate these iniquities, but he failed, and disgusted, he travelled to Rome to beg the Holy Father for counsel. And he said unto him: “My son, if you are incapable of leading your people, then redraw and at least try to save yourself”. And he wanted to journey to Jerusalem, but it was impossible to pass himself off as a common pilgrim, for his bishop’s vestments gave him away, but cast them aside he could not. And he gave his possessions to the poor and he did cast aside his vestments, and he secluded himself in a Benedictine monastery for several years. But here as well he did see how morality had been degraded and how the monks lived a nearly earthly life and in disgust he departed and returned to pastoring and the crosier.<br/> <br/> To rectify at least some things, he founded Brevnov Monastery as well as several others and invited monks of great morals to them to live and devote themselves to God according to the strictest monastic laws. In the year of our Lord 995 a horrible catastrophe struck his family—every last man and child was murdered at the fortified town of Libice, whence only Adalbert escaped, perhaps because he was not there or because no soul dared lay a hand upon a bishop. People evil of tongue claim that it was the Přemyslid clan that did commit this massacre to solidify its power in Bohemia. Others say that it was Adalbert himself who was responsible, for he offered an adulterous wife, who according to custom should have been killed, asylum in his church and thus the disgraced clan of the husband wanted vengeance, but not finding him at Libice, they killed his family instead.<br/> <br/> Sorrowed and disgusted, Adalbert once again retired from his affairs and set off as a missionary to the north, to the land of the pagan Prussians. There he desired to spread the Christian faith and to fight against the pagans’ idolatry, but the local inhabitants did not wish to see him and greeted him with stones and sticks. Seeing such idolatry, he destroyed their idols and chopped down their sacred grove, for they did bow before trees and considered them to be holy. When the pagans saw this, they killed Adalbert and their trees did drink his blood and his body they left there. It was only Boleslaus the Brave who had the holy remains of this martyr taken to Prague.</p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'>《圣阿达尔贝特》 </font></p> <br/><p align='left'> 波西米亚王国的第一任主教，迪特马尔主教逝世后，来自斯莱韦尼克部落的沃伊特克，又名阿达尔贝特，继承了主教之位。这件事发生在982年。想起了先驱的警示：众生之间，邪恶弥漫；贵族之间，通奸盛行；杀戮不止，血泊成河；圣殿沦落，奸商横行；教徒为奴，异端四起，于是他决心与这一切罪孽做输死抗争。五年以来，他致力于消除这些罪孽，但他失败了，绝望了，游历到罗马，向教皇求助。教皇对他说：“我的孩子，修身，齐家，治国，才能平天下，如果你发现自己没有能力领导人民，至少退一步，先修养身性。”之后，他想继续游历到耶路撒冷，但是他无法把这次游历当作一场朝圣，因为他的教袍已将他出卖，但他拒绝抛弃理想。他将教袍与世俗之物施舍给了穷人，自己则进入了一座本笃修道院隐修多年。但是，在修道院里，他又目睹了道德的沦丧，那些僧侣几乎过着世俗的生活。失望之极的他，离开了修道院，转而成为一位神职牧师。 <br/> <br/> 为了至少改变一点现状，他建立了布雷诺夫修道院，以及不少其他的修道院，邀请天下有道德的僧侣前来隐修，全心全意地遵循隐修士教规，服侍上帝。公元995年，他的家园受到了一场大灾难的洗劫-利比采的所有居民，不论老少，尽数被赶尽杀绝，只有阿达尔贝特逃过一劫，可能因为他当时不在场，或是没有人胆敢碰主教一根汗毛。有谗言说，是普莱米索部落实施的屠杀，以巩固他们在波西米亚的统治。也有人说，罪魁祸首乃是阿达尔贝特本人，他为一位本该被处死的通奸女性提供了避难所，因此这位女性的丈夫自觉受到了侮辱，便带领部落前来复仇，只不过没有在利比采发现阿达尔贝特的踪影，他们血洗了他的家庭。 <br/> <br/> 悲伤绝望的阿达尔贝特又一次选择隐退，出发向北方传教，来到了普鲁士异端的领地。他在那里传播基督教信仰，抵制异教的邪神崇拜，但当地的居民却不接受他，冲他扔石块，挥舞棍棒，以示威胁。看到这群原住民跪在树前祈祷，将大树尊为神圣之物，他毁掉了这些邪神，砍掉了他们的神圣林地。被异教徒发现以后，他们处死了阿达尔贝特，用他的血祭奠他们的树神，将他的尸体抛弃在原地。后来，“勇敢者”波尔斯劳斯将他的神圣遗骸带回了布拉格。</p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'>On Simony</font></p> <br/><p align='left'> May the Pope be called a simonist and seller of indulgences? It would seem that he may not, for he is, after all, the master of the whole world, whom it behoves to take what he will and how much and to act as he pleases, and that he is the Most Holy Father, who cannot be besmirched by sin. Let it be known that many Popes have been and are heretics and otherwise evildoers and should be dethroned; and much could be written thereof... And therefore do not doubt that the Pope may be a simonist! And he who would insist that the Pope may not be accused of simony or other mortal sins, he, it seems, would raise him up above Peter and the other Apostles. And what of that, that he is the master of this world who is immune to sin and may act as he pleases? The answer to that is that the only master of this world is God and it is only He who can do all things and only He who is without sin, and not the Pope.<br/> <br/> Perhaps you will say: "Here on Earth the Pope is the Most Holy Father!" I tell you, if you can show me proof that he truly lives most holy and does so act, that he follows Christ in poverty, in humility, in meekness, temperance, moral cleanliness and labour, then I will believe you that he is the holiest of the holy. Only instead of that I see covetousness, pride and other sins that show he truly is not holy. And what of it, that I claim something other than the rest of the world, which allows the holiness of the Pope and regards him as infallible and without sin? Who then are you to believe? I tell you: even if everyone on Earth should call him holy, while in truth he has turned away from Christ, he shall not be holy only because he is called so. It is not words, but deeds, that matter before the court of God. </p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'> 《买卖圣职》 </font></p> <br/><p align='left'> 教皇该被称为圣职与放纵的卖主吗？这看起来似乎是不可能的，毕竟他是全世界的主人，理应随心所欲，自由行事，而且他是最神圣的父，绝不会被罪孽所堕落。我们要知道，这世界上凭空出来许多教皇，很多都是异端邪说之人，行罪恶之事，应该被废；很多看上去是真相的东西都应该做做文章......因此，不要怀疑，教皇可能就是在买卖圣职！而那些坚持认为教皇没有在干买卖圣职及其他诸多罪行的人，似乎会被加冕至彼得和其他使徒之上。而且，究竟为什么，他成为了这个世界的主人，免于世间一切的罪恶，可以无法无天地行事呢？我的回答是，这个世界唯一的主人是上帝，只有他能做所有的事情，只有他是无罪的，而不是教皇。<br/> <br/> 也许你们会说：“在尘世，教皇是最神圣的父！”我告诉你们，如果你们能向我证明他确实是最圣洁的人，以谦卑，温柔，节制，道德的清洁与劳动，简朴，虔诚地跟随基督，我便相信你们，尊他为最神圣之人。而我却只看到了他的贪婪，骄傲和其他诸多罪恶，表明他确实是不洁之人。那么，我凭什么还要称这个教皇是圣洁之人，把他视为无误的圣人，没有任何罪孽？这样的话，我们该相信谁呢？我告诉你们，即使尘世间的每个人都应该称他为圣人，他实际已然背叛了基督，因此他配不上圣洁的名号。这不是空口无凭，而是证据确凿的，一切都将面临上帝的审判。 </p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'>Ye Wicked Blacksmiths</font></p> <br/><p align='left'>Blacksmiths, let ye pay good heed; <br/>And stoop not to dishonest deeds, <br/> Which some do, caring not a jot, <br/> As sinful you regard it not, <br/>Tools of wicked trade to make <br/>Unscrupulously for profit’s sake. <br/> <br/>A thief comes creeping, out of sight, <br/>To your house in darkest night <br/>And says, ''Master, rise and shine, <br/>I’ll reward you well with coin, <br/>If you'll just forge secretly <br/>Certain implements for me. <br/>Forge for me a powerful saw <br/>That will cut even iron right through, <br/>That nothing can resist at all, <br/>Whether it be big or small; <br/>And also a dagger of sharpest steel <br/>That I can beneath my cloak conceal. <br/> <br/>Forge me ten strong keys as well, <br/>Better than any in Heaven or Hell, <br/>Which will open any lock on Earth. <br/>Blacksmith, give me my money’s worth!” <br/>Thus with promise of reward <br/>He tempts the master with honeyed words. <br/> <br/>This the blacksmith gladly hears; <br/> The thief’s words music to his ears. <br/> “All the tools that you may need, <br/> I shall willingly forge indeed! <br/>All that you ask I’ll deliver, <br/>As long as you pay me in silver!” <br/> <br/>“With Groschen we will fill your purse <br/>When you bring these things to us! <br/>Come to us in the deepest woods, <br/>Where our merry band will await your goods. <br/>God gifted you with golden hands, <br/>But riches you’ll get from a robbers’ band!” <br/> <br/>The smith’s bargain with the thief is done; <br/>Honour and conscience he has none. <br/> He’d sell his soul to anyone!</p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'>Ye Wicked Blacksmiths</font></p> <br/><p align='left'>Blacksmiths, let ye pay good heed; <br/>And stoop not to dishonest deeds, <br/> Which some do, caring not a jot, <br/> As sinful you regard it not, <br/>Tools of wicked trade to make <br/>Unscrupulously for profit’s sake. <br/> <br/>A thief comes creeping, out of sight, <br/>To your house in darkest night <br/>And says, ''Master, rise and shine, <br/>I’ll reward you well with coin, <br/>If you'll just forge secretly <br/>Certain implements for me. <br/>Forge for me a powerful saw <br/>That will cut even iron right through, <br/>That nothing can resist at all, <br/>Whether it be big or small; <br/>And also a dagger of sharpest steel <br/>That I can beneath my cloak conceal. <br/> <br/>Forge me ten strong keys as well, <br/>Better than any in Heaven or Hell, <br/>Which will open any lock on Earth. <br/>Blacksmith, give me my money’s worth!” <br/>Thus with promise of reward <br/>He tempts the master with honeyed words. <br/> <br/>This the blacksmith gladly hears; <br/> The thief’s words music to his ears. <br/> “All the tools that you may need, <br/> I shall willingly forge indeed! <br/>All that you ask I’ll deliver, <br/>As long as you pay me in silver!” <br/> <br/>“With Groschen we will fill your purse <br/>When you bring these things to us! <br/>Come to us in the deepest woods, <br/>Where our merry band will await your goods. <br/>God gifted you with golden hands, <br/>But riches you’ll get from a robbers’ band!” <br/> <br/>The smith’s bargain with the thief is done; <br/>Honour and conscience he has none. <br/> He’d sell his soul to anyone!</p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'>On Evil Morals in Bohemia</font></p> <br/><p align='left'> The Czechs have ceased to preserve their good name and sinfully devote themselves to hedonistic delights. The old of their ilk stuff themselves like pigs and merely idle about in their homes, whilst the young have taken to dog hunting. The noblemen have begun to do that which once behoved only servants. Where once each lord kept his house clean and orderly, now dogs lie there; where ere hunters hunted and lords would come to visit them as need be, today they have devoted themselves to this lowly art, as if they had forgotten about their own blood. Ere they would sit at a table and attend to the affairs of the land and see to the multiplication of its peace and wealth; today they are wont to share a roof with a dog of the hunt and consider conversation of dogs and hunting to be of the most honourable variety. And thus the wealth of their estates is deteriorating and the stench of their dogs shall soon kill them.<br/> <br/> In days of yore when they set off to war, their own country they did not loot and took only from the enemy. Yet what of today? When they depart upon a military campaign, their first action is plunder to their own country. In times ere they dared not touch the property of the Holy Church and honoured it rightly. Today they have no shame in plundering churches and monasteries. Without honour they return from battle; having molested young maidens and drunk every drop of mead, they return home like drunken beasts and new injustices do perpetrate… Not a single crumb of honour is left in these once proud Czechs. And a time will come when they shall cry over their gain and only gladly return to the old ways and order.</p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'> 《波西米亚邪恶的品德》 </font></p> <br/><p align='left'> 捷克人辜负了自己的名望，堕入了享乐主义的深渊。成人们蜗居在家中，游手好闲，而青年们则整天狩猎取乐。贵族们也做起了奴仆的差事。曾经的领主，将各自的殿堂打扫得干净整洁，大气明亮，而现在那里却成了犬儒之窝；曾经的领主，只有必要的时候才会与猎人为伍，而现在他们却一同享受这种低劣的游戏，好像他们已全然忘记了自己高贵的血统。曾经的领主，勤理朝政，关心地方的治安与发展；而现在他们却自愿与猎犬共享同一个屋檐，将与狗的交流及狩猎看成最荣耀的事务。如此下去，捷克将落得国破人亡，犬臭熏天的地步。 <br/> <br/> 缅怀曾经战无不胜的日子，他们保卫家园不受掠夺，在战场上收获敌人的战利品。而如今怎样？一旦有军号吹响，他们第一个掠夺的是自己的家园。曾经，他们从不敢碰神圣的教会的财产，而且尊重教会，保护教会。而现在，他们竟敢毫不知耻地掠夺教堂和修道院。战场上他们一败涂地；侵犯民女，嗜酒如命，回家时已然堕落成了一头烂醉如泥的野兽，更是为非作歹，无法无天……曾经骄傲无比的捷克人，如今已名誉扫地。总有一天，他们会忏悔自己的堕落，想要重铸昨日的荣光。 </p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'>The Peculiar Siege of Prague</font></p> <br/><p align='left'> In the year of our Lord 1401, in the summer after the prince-electors stripped King Wenceslas of the title of Holy Roman Emperor due to his inability and unwillingness to rule, the army of Jobst, Margrave of Moravia, and the League of Lords appeared before the gates of Prague, alongside the armies of William of Meissen with the support of Prokop, the cousin of the king, who was initially sent to William to discourage him from war, but in the end he joined with him. Together they laid siege to the town from two sides, from north and south, but their strength was not so great that they could take the town by storm or even to fully encircle its walls. King Wenceslas did not want to come out of the safety the town walls with his army, so all the armies remained in place and waited to see what would happen. And none of those laying siege wanted to send their army against Prague to destroy it, for they did not wish to cause any injury to the Kingdom of Bohemia, but only force Wenceslas to capitulate and relinquish the Crown of Bohemia.<br/> <br/> Sigismund of Luxembourg, who had been vying for the throne, remained at that time in the captivity of his own subjects and thus he could not come to the aid of either side. It is said that if he were to have come to the aid of someone, he would have likely helped his brother Wenceslas, although he had warred with him at other times, because blood is blood and it would be preferable for the crown to stay in the family. The besiegers of Prague kept up their siege and even brought food and supplies to the people of Prague, for rowdy soldiers did not plunder the surrounding area and spared the farms. Seeing this willingness of this army, the army of Prague had no desire whatsoever to commit to violent deeds. <br/> <br/> Seventeen days did the armies lay siege, seventeen days did they negotiate and make schemes so complicated that many got lost in them and they began to conspire against each other. On the seventeenth day Jobst and the League of Lords came to an agreement with King Wenceslas that the former will not have to relinquish the crown, but decision-making and government shall be left to the nobles from then on and that he should endeavor no more to rule. William, seeing that no fruits would be borne, retreated with his army back to Meissen. <br/> <br/> The peculiar siege ended without loos of life or injury. The only one to suffer loss was Wenceslas, for the soldiers in the royal siege encampments had slaughtered all the game in the royal preserve to fill their bellies.</p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'> 《布拉格之围》 </font></p> <br/><p align='left'> 公元1401年，在选帝侯因瓦茨拉夫不理朝政而将其废黜之后的夏天，摩拉维亚伯爵，约布斯特与领主联盟的大军大举逼近布拉格的城门。在他们身边，还有迈森的威廉与普罗科普的联军。普罗科普是国王的表兄，最初曾劝说威廉退出战争，但后来还是与他联合了起来。这些军队从南北方向围攻布拉格，但他们的兵力并没有强大到迅速占领外围城镇，或者将四面的城墙团团围住。瓦茨拉夫国王不想出兵挑起大战，所以守军全部待命，静观其变。而所有围城的军队也不想派兵洗劫布拉格，因为他们不想对波西米亚的同胞造成伤害，只想逼迫瓦茨拉夫投降，交出波西米亚的王位。 <br/> <br/> 卢森堡的西格斯蒙德，觑觎王位已久，时年为其部下所擒，未能赶来战场助战。据说，倘若他能前来助战，一定会出手帮助他的兄弟。尽管二人曾多次交手，但血浓于水，应尽可能保证王冠在家族内传承。围攻布拉格的士兵没有进攻，甚至还为布拉格民众提供食物等供给，而暴躁的士兵也没有洗劫周围的村镇，也放过了那些农场。看到了敌人诚恳的态度，布拉格的士兵也无心恋战了。 <br/> <br/> 围城持续了十七天。整整十七天，他们都在试图交涉，计划愈发复杂，甚至引起了内讧。在第十七天，约布斯特和领主联盟与瓦茨拉夫国王达成了一致，前者不再执着废黜国王，但政府的决策权从此交付贵族，从而剥夺了瓦茨拉夫治理国家的权力。看到战事与谈判毫无结果，威廉的部队撤退回了迈森。 <br/> <br/> 这场特殊的围攻战最终没有造成任何人员伤亡。唯一受到损失的人就是瓦茨拉夫，因为围城的士兵杀光了皇家猎场的所有猎物以充饥。 </p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'>Song of the Merry Poor</font></p> <br/><p align='left'>Now has winter come, <br/>Hear you, ragged ones! <br/>Evil times are on us<br/>And clothing none! <br/>Evil winds blow, <br/>Evil is sown! <br/>Blasts of bitter weather, <br/>One upon another, <br/>Bringing nought but bother<br/> <br/>Heavy falls the snow, <br/>Foretelling great woe! <br/>Worn threadbare your cloak, <br/>Hose torn and shoes are broke. <br/>We sleep through summer<br/>Heedless in slumber<br/>Of next winter’s snows. <br/>How great our woes, <br/>How poor our clothes! <br/> <br/>Ye poor, be of good cheer, <br/>Joy is with us here! <br/>Clothes worn away, <br/>Heads turned to grey! <br/>Despair, poor ones, <br/>Shall guide us on, <br/>What can we endeavour? <br/>Our path forever<br/>To seek God’s favour. <br/> <br/>Caps from our heads torn, <br/>None is left to keep. <br/>What grief we have sown<br/>So shall we yet reap! <br/>Sheaves cut short<br/>And sad of heart. <br/>In Bohemia what to do, <br/>But to the tavern go, <br/>For relief from woe? <br/> <br/>And at the alehouse then, <br/>They give us nought to drink, <br/>Oh, what misery to sup<br/>From a dry and empty cup! <br/>Pawn accursed, <br/>with empty purse. <br/>What can you endeavour? <br/>Seek relief from labour, <br/>And ask God’s favour. <br/> <br/>On Friday here’s our fare: <br/>Soup from water prepared, <br/>Stew of grass and wood; <br/>An end to this bad food! <br/>Fish will there be, <br/>From Danube or sea? <br/>Of that there’s little fear, <br/>For even eels are dear, <br/>And loach are far from here. <br/> <br/>On Saturday we’ll sup, <br/>From grief’s bitter cup. <br/>And on Sunday morning, <br/>Empty bellies groaning. <br/>At table together, <br/>One poor as another, <br/>We’ll sit and take our share<br/>Of nothing else but air<br/>And let that be our fare. <br/> <br/>The cooks for us will brew<br/>From mist and fog a stew, <br/>From darkness roasted game<br/>And venison in dreams, <br/>Stew a log of wood<br/>Or a club for food, <br/>To honour guests and treat them. <br/>Such food they serve to feed them<br/>Would better serve to beat them! <br/> <br/>Keep your food so rough. <br/>Black pudding with barley<br/>And cabbage we love, <br/>Buttermilk and whey, <br/>Mashed peas, <br/>Noodles with seeds<br/>Of poppy, smoked ham too, <br/>A pumpkin or two, <br/>And chickpea stew!</p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'> 贫民之歌 </font></p> <br/><p align='left'>凛冬已至， <br/>听着，你们这群地痞！ <br/>日子一天比一天难熬 <br/>我们连件衣服都没搞到！ <br/>恶魔的风呼啸而过， <br/>将撒旦的种子撒播！ <br/>寒冷的侵袭， <br/>一日胜过一日， <br/>只让人苦恼不已 <br/> <br/>大雪纷飞不停， <br/>预言着灾祸无情！ <br/>你的袍子褴褛不堪， <br/>靴子踏破，鞋子踩烂。 <br/>我们睡过了炎夏 <br/>美梦的帷幕还没落下 <br/>隆冬的雪便将我们冻醒。 <br/>灾祸是多么无情, <br/>我们的衣衫是如此八碎七零！ <br/> <br/>穷鬼们，兴奋起来， <br/>欢愉与我们同在！ <br/>扔掉衣裳， <br/>转眼白发苍苍！ <br/>穷鬼们，是绝望， <br/>将我们引航， <br/>我们又能奈何？ <br/>这条道路永远严苛， <br/>听天由命，等待千载一合。 <br/> <br/>帽子也是残破， <br/>再无其他选择。 <br/>我们昔日将悲哀撒播 <br/>今日就要自食苦果！ <br/>割下一捆捆的哀伤 <br/>以及心灵的凄凉。 <br/>波西米亚，是如此荒芜 <br/>只有酒馆暂且一住，<br/>可否获得悲惨中的援助？ <br/> <br/>而在那酒馆之中，<br/>他们不给我们酒盅， <br/>哦，我们只剩啜饮忧伤 <br/>独自面对那杯中空荡！ <br/>诅咒那当铺， <br/>让它分文不入。 <br/>你们又能奈何？ <br/>用劳动换解脱， <br/>听天由命，等待千载一合。 <br/> <br/>星期五，我们这样过活： <br/>河水煮的汤已经齐活，<br/>乱炖青草和树皮； <br/>不要再吃这种垃圾！ <br/>那里会有鱼吗， <br/>来自多瑙还是海峡？ <br/>这倒不用担心， <br/>鳗鱼便已是精品， <br/>泥鳅更是足够令人欢欣。 <br/> <br/>星期六，我们会痛饮，<br/>将悲伤的苦水一饮而尽。 <br/>星期天早上， <br/>咆哮是肚子空荡。 <br/>围在桌子前， <br/>一个比一个穷酸， <br/>我们坐下来，议论分成 <br/>什么都没有，只剩西风 <br/>这便是我们的人生。 <br/> <br/>做好我们的午饭 <br/>就着雾霾用餐， <br/>想象着野味的烤香 <br/>鹿肉只存在于梦乡，<br/>再下锅木头一根 <br/>或是一截木棍， <br/>以热情招待我们的客人。 <br/>与其用这种食物款待他们 <br/>还不如用它来将他们暴揍一顿！ <br/> <br/>吃你的粗茶淡饭。 <br/>我们要黑布丁配大麦 <br/>我们热爱卷心菜， <br/>我们要乳酪和乳清陪伴， <br/>我们要豆泥， <br/>种子做的面食 <br/>要罂粟的种子，还要熏火腿， <br/>偶尔来一两个南瓜刺激味蕾， <br/>乱炖鹰嘴豆也要可口美味！ </p>

<p align='center'><font size='32'> The Groom to the Scholar</font></p><br/><p align='center'> Scholar, you wretched fellow! <br/>How can you so boldly bellow? <br/>You, with no coin to your name <br/>gaunt and afraid of the cane, <br/>Trudging through this world in squalor,<br/>Ever burdened by your labour. <br/>However you may toil and sweat, <br/>No better garments shall you get. <br/>To go in rags is a pupil’s lot, <br/>A bed to lie on you have not. <br/>Now you lie by the hearth at night, <br/>But in winter you will have to fight <br/>to warm your bones by the fireside near<br/>for they’ll drive you out without a care. <br/>You’d be blessed to sleep on the floor at least, <br/>Not left to lie on the earth like a beast. <br/>Shivering on the frozen ground, <br/>with chattering teeth and frost all round. <br/>And still you’ll have no end to chores, <br/>Lighting the stove and sweeping floors, <br/>Your work may never be forgot, <br/>although you cannot sleep a jot <br/>when on the cold hard ground you lay. <br/>I'm better off, I proudly say. <br/>My bed of straw is like Paradise, <br/>where at night I peacefully lie<br/>like a bird in a feathered nest of spruce. <br/>Though at times I lie in dung, God’s truth. -<br/>but still I suffer little pain, <br/>save when I am soaked by rain, <br/>I must wait till dawn and my clothing dries, <br/>And I wipe it clean as soon as I rise <br/>so the cloth is clean and bright next day. <br/>Mark my words, one thing I’ll say: <br/>the peasants fear me to a man! <br/>Wherever I may walk or stand, <br/>all bow their heads before me low: <br/>"Welcome, Master!”, they greet me so, <br/>Even the farmer steps aside <br/>and the chickens can hardly run and hide<br/>I’m glad of that, for if they will, <br/>let them hide in my bag until, <br/>I take them with me to a feast -<br/>plucked and cooked in their own grease! <br/>One thing I’ll say, since you entreat me: <br/>I have no fear my lord will beat me.</p>$new_page;

<p align='center'><font size='32'> 《臭老九》 </font></p><br/><p align='center'> 学者，你这可怜的家伙！ <br/>为何还敢乱讲胡说！ <br/>你们一文不值，空有虚名 <br/>渺小懦弱，畏惧鞭挞之刑， <br/>肮脏地在世间游荡乞讨， <br/>却仍备受辛劳。 <br/>你挥洒汗水，饱尝艰辛 <br/>却得不到更好的衣襟。 <br/>学生的命运乃是褴褛破烂， <br/>你找不到床铺去入梦阑珊。 <br/>今夜你在炉边躺下休息， <br/>而冬天你又要抗争到底 <br/>也无法找到火堆温暖你的身体 <br/>因为人们把你驱赶到荒山野地。 <br/>你该庆幸能够睡在地板上， <br/>而不是像个野兽昏睡于大地苍茫。 <br/>冰封的大地上你瑟瑟发颤， <br/>牙齿打架，全身冻烂。 <br/>只是你的劳作远未结束， <br/>打扫地面，点起火炉。 <br/>他们总不会忘了让你干活， <br/>尽管你一点觉都没有睡过 <br/>在那又冷又硬的地上躺着。 <br/>我可以骄傲地说，我的境况要好得多。 <br/>我的稻草床铺就像伊甸， <br/>夜里我可以躺在上面安然入眠 <br/>就像鸟儿钻进了云杉上的巢。 <br/>尽管有时我会睡在粪堆里，上帝知晓，- <br/>比起来，我的痛苦还是太小， <br/>就算有时我会被雨倾盆灌浇， <br/>衣服要晾干，只能等到黎明， <br/>起床以后，我要抓紧把它们洗干净 <br/>第二天又如同新衣一般光洁闪亮。 <br/>听好了，有件事我要明讲： <br/>那些贱民全都怕我！ <br/>只要走到他们之间，或者他们远远见到我 <br/>他们都要对我点头哈腰： <br/>“欢迎，大人！”他们会这样向我问好。 <br/>连农夫都会谦卑地退让 <br/>家禽吓得不再躲藏 <br/>我很欣慰，如果他们愿意， <br/>我会把他们装进口袋里， <br/>把他们带去野餐- <br/>享受一场人肉盛宴！<br/>话说在前面，既然你已诚恳地向我乞求： <br/>没有哪个领主的鞭子会令我低头。 </p>$new_page;

<p align='center'><font size='32'> The Scholar to the Groom</font></p><br/><p align='center'>You are but a rag from the stable! <br/>How oft have you food on your table? <br/>Slender you are as a weed, <br/>no better than a peasant indeed, <br/>mucking out dung every day<br/>no better thing comes your way. <br/>With a scholar you cannot compare - <br/>whose prospects are better than fair. <br/>Unlike you, you rabble unlearned! <br/>God willing, one day I’ll have earned <br/>a bishop’s mitre and crosier, <br/>for I labour to make my life rosier. <br/>Unless fortune should prove contrary, <br/>I’ll soon go to the famed seminary, <br/>in pursuit of my true aspiration, <br/>to gain my first ordination. <br/>And who would dare to spite me <br/>when I am high and mighty,<br/>in golden robes of fabric grand, <br/>a priest or prelate of the land? <br/>While I shall preach from the pulpit, <br/>you will stand like a guilty culprit<br/>in your stinking rags at your prayer, <br/>shrinking under my glare. <br/>You wretched bearer of ill-will, <br/>put aside your conceit and be still, <br/>Save your quarrels and your curses - <br/>men’s worth is not in their purses! <br/>Be wise and heed my advice: <br/>if you wish for a long happy life, <br/>abandon your stable and your rabble! </p>

<p align='center'><font size='32'> 《臭马夫》 </font></p><br/><p align='center'>你不过是马厩里出来的破烂！ <br/>多久才会在餐桌上吃一次饭？ <br/>瘦削的样子像根杂草， <br/>身体都没有那帮佃农好， <br/>每天都在铲着马屎 <br/>没有比这更好的差事。 <br/>那些学者你根本比不上- <br/>他们的智慧渊博高尚。 <br/>不像你，愚昧无知的乌合之众！ <br/>上天可鉴，总一天我会继承 <br/>主教的法冠与权杖， <br/>因为我辛勤劳作，为了生活更有希望。 <br/>除非命运让我事与愿违， <br/>我将进入有名的神学院进修学位， <br/>追求我真正的理想， <br/>获得我的第一个神职嘉奖。 <br/>届时何人敢小看我的辛劳 <br/>当我攀上高峰，无限荣耀，<br/>穿上瑰丽的金袍， <br/>成为牧师，或者教员，为国家奉献到老？ <br/>当我在讲台上布道， <br/>你们就站在底下如同罪犯求饶 <br/>穿着你那件破烂的衣裳祷告， <br/>在我深邃的注视下跪倒。 <br/>你这可怜的恶意之人， <br/>卸下你的伪装，捡起你的责任， <br/>省省你那血口喷人的满嘴污言- <br/>人的价值不在于身上的金钱！ <br/>用心倾听我的建议： <br/>如果你想活得更有意义， <br/>离开你的马厩，还有你的狐朋狗友！ </p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'>On Prague</font></p> <br/><p align='left'> The seat of the kings of Bohemia, a city of grandness, whose glory reaches to the heavens. Amongst the great cities of the world, it is the greatest, rich in commerce and strong in arms, and endowed with beauty, the towers of which rise above other towns. Founded by Princes Libusse and Přemysl, her husband and the father of the Přemyslid Dynasty, with a castle of stone at a place called Hradčany, to which later quarters were adjoined and during the reign of Emporer Charles the whole of the New Town was built on the opposite bank of the Vltava River, with the largest stone bridge the world had ever seen connecting it to the Old Town, made of much stone and mortar, to which, according to legend, thousands of eggs were added for greater strength.<br/> <br/> The population is of a diverse nature. The Czechs dominate, but many a German can be found amongst merchants and tradesmen, who live in their own quarter, and even the Jews have been granted their own “town” within Prague, into which no Christian dare step foot. To celebrate the glory of God, the One and Only, monasteries were founded at Emmaus, Strahov, and Klarov, and churches of stone are so numerous that you could not count them on two hands. The greatest and most renowned of all, consecrated to Saints Vitus and Aldabert, shall soon stand, for it has been being constructed for nearly fifty years and soon shall be completed. Under Emperor Charles a University was founded as well, which provides learning in four arts, and from many distant lands do foreigners come to study. If one was to visit only one city in life, may one make haste to Prague, for there is no more beautiful city in the world.</p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'> 《布拉格》 </font></p> <br/><p align='left'> 波西米亚之王座，辉煌之城，荣光闪耀天界。她是万城之王，商业发达，男丁充足，女子秀美，高塔凌驾于其他城镇之上。她由丽波瑟王后及其丈夫，也就是普莱米索王朝之父，普莱米索建立。最初于雷德卡尼建起了一座城堡，之后其他区划也相继发展起来，在查理国王统治时期，新城也于伏尔塔瓦河对岸拔地而起。新旧两个城区由世界上最大的石桥连通，桥梁由石头和泥灰建成，据传，加入了成千上万的蛋清来加固桥身。 <br/> <br/> 这里人种多样。绝大部分为捷克人，也有通商的德国人，住在他们的聚集区，甚至连犹太人也在布拉格被赋予了属于他们自己的“小镇”，没有基督教徒胆敢踏足。为了赞美上帝的恩典，在这座独一无二的城市里，埃莫，斯特拉霍夫，科罗拉夫，有大小修道院，石头教堂比比皆是，数不清个数。最宏伟著名的，当属工期五十余年，仍在建设的圣维特斯和阿尔德伯特大教堂。在查理国王在位时期，城里也建起了一座大学，教授四艺（算数、几何、天文、音乐），吸引了很多外邦学生前来求学。如果人一生只有机会去一座城市游览，速来布拉格，因为她是天下最美的城市。</p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'>Remedies for Fleas and Warts</font></p> <br/><p align='left'> Scabies and growths of the skin of all manner, the same as insects and all low, crawling creatures, have been the bane of mankind since time immemorial. For he who wishes to protect his body, he must sleep less amongst cattle, at least once a fortnight wash himself in water or visit a bath, and expose his clothes to the sun. For water and sun drive away all ailments of the skin, whilst sickness does flourish where there is the filth and stench of the human body. Keep distance from vagrants and beggars, for it is they who are the greatest bearers of illness and they can easily infect you. </p>$new_page;

<p align='center'><font size='25'> 《跳蚤和肉赘的治疗措施》 </font></p> <br/><p align='left'> 疥疮和各种皮疹，与害虫鼠辈一样，自古以来便是人类之敌。倘若有人想保护自己的身体免受侵害，他需尽量避免与牛群同寝，至少每两周清洗一次身体，或者光临澡堂，同时，要将衣服放在阳光下晾晒。之所以这样做，乃是因为清水与阳光取走皮肤上的病害，而病害专门在人体脏臭之处滋生。不要接近浪人与乞丐，因为他们是病害的传播者，可以轻易地将皮肤病传染给你。 </p>$new_page;

<p align='center'><font size='32'>Fleas</font></p><br/><p align='left'> Take a new pot and grease it well with goat’s lard, and it shall draw all fleas into it or they shall congregate around it. You may also pour a decoction of wormwood in your hearth room. It is also said that fleas shall die when in your hearth room you boil wolf’s dung or wormwood with rue. But there is nothing surer than oft sweeping the floors of debris with a broom and every morn hanging and drying your bedding in the sun. It is likewise advisable to take a warm bath, but if the bath is not warm, then cold will suffice as well, and to have your clothes laundered and dried in the sun. If you follow these instructions, you are sure to rid yourself of fleas.</p>$new_page;

<p align='center'><font size='32'> 《跳蚤》 </font></p><br/><p align='left'> 去一个新的罐子，用山羊的油浸泡好，它便会把所有的跳蚤都吸进去，或者将它们聚集在周围。 你也可以在炉房里倒一点艾草。据说，跳蚤一旦跑到了炉房，你就可以煎煮狼粪或芸香和艾草，把跳蚤熏死。但是没有什么比时常用扫帚打扫地板，以及每天早晨在阳光下晾晒被褥的更可靠的了。洗温水澡也是明智之举，但如果洗澡水不温暖，冷水也足够了，并且要在阳光下晾晒衣服。按照这些说明做，你一定能摆脱跳蚤。</p>$new_page;

<p align='center'><font size='32'>Warts</font></p><br/><p align='left'> Take young dandelions and apply a thick layer of their milk to warts and they shall die. Or take groundsel (Lat. Senico) and churn it and mix it with liquid vinegar and apply it to warts. Or rub them oft with but salt and warm vinegar. Or take a grey-spotted Amanita mushroom and rub it on a wart. In all of these manners can you rid yourself of warts. You should not cut them off with a knife, nor should you burn them with a hot iron, for then they shall quickly return, and often in greater abundance.</p>

<p align='center'><font size='32'> 《肉赘》 </font></p><br/><p align='left'> 取来初生的蒲公英，贴在肉赘上，再往上面涂一层牛奶，肉赘便消失了。或者用千里光，将它搅碎，用液体醋混合，并且将它敷到肉赘上。或者用盐和温醋揉搓。或者用一个灰色斑点鹅膏菌蘑菇，并在肉赘上擦试。通过这些方式，你便可以摆脱肉赘。你不应该用刀子把它们砍掉，也不应该用热铁把它们烫掉，因为这样它们会很快长回来，而且往往会比之前更加猖獗。 </p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'>Rattay</font></p> <br/><p align='left'> Nigh five hundred years have passed since the appearance of a walled settlement, which later grew into a castle guarding the borders of the land of the Zlicans and its main trade route, and even later it bloomed into a town, which, however, one-hundred-and-fifty years ago burned to the ground and was built anew in even more beautiful form, with strong walls that not even Kutna Hora or Prague need be ashamed of. The fortified town of Rattay fell under the possession of the King, and was granted as a fiefdom, and during the reign of John of Luxembourg it fell under the rule of Lord Henry of Lipa, who then had built a lower castle that they called Pirkstein. Today, Rattay is under the administration of Hanush until young Lord Capon of Lipa reaches adulthood and unto him shall be granted the whole town and its surrounding estates as a fiefdom. <br/> In Rattay all manners of tradesmen flourish––butchers, smiths, tailors, weavers, and armourers––and great markets are held here every month. Rattay is an administrative centre and thus can afford to employ its own executioner and support a strong municipal garrison. Its large stone church is consecrated to Saint Matthew.</p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'> 《拉泰》 </font></p> <br/><p align='left'> 自第一个拥有围墙的村镇建立起来，已经过去了五百余年。在漫长的历史长河里，这个村镇发展成了一座城堡，保卫着兹利的边疆，以及她的主要通商路线。后来，城堡又发展成为一座城市，只是于一百五十年前毁于一旦。而后又在远处重建起了一座更美丽的城市，坚固的城墙不亚于库特纳霍拉或者布拉格。坚不可摧的拉泰城成为了国王的封地，在卢森堡的约翰统治时期，她又成为了莱佩的亨利领主的属地。领主建起了一座下层城堡，名叫皮克斯坦。如今，拉泰城由瀚纳什治理，直到莱佩的卡蓬少主成年。少主成年以后，他将获得整个城镇以及周围领地的管辖权。 <br/> 拉泰的商业盛行，极具多样化：屠夫，铁匠，裁缝，纺织工，以及军械士。每月都会举行大集市。拉泰是一个行政中心，因此可以雇佣自己的刽子手，供给一支强大的驻军。拉泰还拥有一座献给圣马修的巨大的石头教堂。 </p>

<p align='center'><font size='32'>Silence</font></p> <br/><p align='left'> Let us act in accordance with that saying of the Prophet; "I have said: I will keep my ways, that I offend not with my tongue. I have been watchful over my mouth: I held my peace and humbled myself, and was silent from speaking even good things. If, therefore, according to this saying of the Prophet we are at times to abstain, for silence sake, even from good talk, how much more ought we to refrain from evil words, on account of the guilt and penalty of sin! Therefore, because of the importance of silence, let leave to speak be seldom given, even to perfect disciples although their words be of good and holy matters, tending unto edification; because it is written: “In much speaking, thou shalt not escape sin." And in another place: " Death and life are in the hands of the tongue." For it behoveth a master to speak and teach; and it beseemeth a disciple to hold his peace and listen. If, therefore, anything must be asked of the Prior, let it be done with all humility, subjection, and reverence, that he who asks may not seem to speak more than is necessary. But as for buffoonery, idle words, or such as move to laughter, we utterly condemn and forbid them in all places, nor do we allow a disciple to open his mouth to give them utterance.</p>$new_page;

<p align='center'><font size='32'> 《论缄默》 </font></p> <br/><p align='left'> 我们该遵守先知说的：“我曾说过，我要注意我的道路，免得我的舌头犯罪。我用嚼环勒住我的嘴，我沉静无声，即善言亦不出口。”这里先知指出，若我们为保守缄默的缘故，连圣善的话有时还不当说，那么为怕罪罚的缘故，一切恶话更当禁绝了！所以为了缄默的重要，即使循规蹈矩的弟子，所要讲论的虽有益于神修的善言圣语，也难得许可； 因为圣经说：“多口多舌的，难免咎戾”。他处又说：“生死是在舌的权下。” 因为作师长的宜说话和训人，而静默和听讲却适宜于弟子。所以倘有该向长上询问的事情，必须谦虚敬顺地询问，多说无益。至于滑稽，闲话和逗笑的言谈，不论何处，我们绝对禁止而谴责之，不许弟子开口说这类的话。 </p>$new_page;

<p align='center'><font size='32'>On Daily Manual Labour</font></p> <br/><p align='left'> Idleness is an enemy of the soul. Therefore, the Brethren ought to be employed at certain times in labouring with their hands, and at other fixed times, in holy reading. Wherefore we think that both these occasions may be well ordered thus: From Easter till the first of October, let them, on going forth from Prime, labour at whatever they are required till about the fourth hour. From the fourth, till close upon the sixth hour, let them be employed in reading. On rising from table after the sixth hour, let them rest on their beds with all silence, or if perchance any one shall desire to read, let him read in such a way as not to disturb anyone else. Let None be said seasonably, at about the middle of the eighth hour, and after that let them work at what they have to do till the evening. If the situation of the place, or their poverty require them to labour in reaping their corn, let them not be saddened thereat, for then are they Monks in very deed, when they live by the labour of their hands, as our Fathers and the Apostles did before us. Yet let all things be done with moderation for the sake of the fainthearted.</p>$new_page;

<p align='center'><font size='32'> 《论日常手工》 </font></p> <br/><p align='left'> 空闲是灵魂的仇敌；所以：弟兄们该在一定的时间内从事j操作，又该在一定的时间内阅读圣书。 我们认为这两种时间可以这样规定：即是，自复活节至十月一日，清晨自一时约至四时，弟兄们外出做紧要的工作。自四时至约六时专务读书。念完六时经，离开餐桌后．各在自己的床上全然寂静地休息，若有人愿意念书的，该细声读，以免扰乱他人。八时半提前念九时经；而后再做所当做的工作直到念晚经。倘若任何贫穷的地方需要帮助收获田地，我们便给予他们所需的帮助，毕竟我们都是虔诚的信徒，就像我们的圣父与使徒一样，我们自食其力，靠劳作生活。然而，要帮助懒惰懦弱的人，帮助便要适可而止了。 </p>$new_page;

<p align='center'><font size='32'>On the Obedience of Disciples</font></p> <br/><p align='left'> The first degree of humility is obedience without delay. This beseemeth those who, either through fear of hell or for the glory of life everlasting, count nothing more dear to them than Christ. These, presently, as soon as any- thing is commanded them by the Superior, make no delay in doing it, just as if the command had come from God. This obedience will then be acceptable to God and pleasing to men, if what is commanded be not done fearfully, slowly, coldly, or with murmuring, or an answer showing unwillingness; because the obedience which is given to superiors is given to God, who hath said: " He that heareth you, heareth Me." Hence it ought to be done by the disciples with a good will, because God " loveth a cheerful giver," It the disciple obey with ill-will, and murmur, not only in words, but also in heart, although if he fulfil what is commanded him, it will not be acceptable to God, Who considereth the heart of the murmurer. For such a work he shall not have any reward, but rather incurreth the penalty of murmurers, unless he amend and make satisfaction.</p>$new_page;

<p align='center'><font size='32'> 《论听命》 </font></p> <br/><p align='left'> 高度的谦逊是不迟延的听命。这个德行最适合那些，或因畏惧地狱，或为永生的光荣，而爱待基督在万有之上的人去实践。 这些话的实践便是-几时长上令做什么，他们接受之，一如天主所命，不容延迟，立即执行。惟不犹豫，不迟慢，不怠惰，不抱怨，不反驳推辞，而奉行所命的事，这听命才能见纳于主，见悦于人。因为服从长上的，便是服从天主，天主有云：“听从你们的，就是听从我的。”从命之人必须乐意服从，因为“捐得乐意的人，是上帝所喜爱的。”若是弟子恶意听命，不但口说怨言，而且心有不甘，表面虽遵行了命令，但他的行为不能见悦于天主，因为天主洞见埋怨者的心。这样的工作，一点圣宠也得不到，若他不补赎自新，还要因怨言而招来惩罚。</p>$new_page;

<p align='center'><font size='32'>The Abbot</font></p> <br/><p align='left'> When, therefore, anyone taketh upon himself the name of Abbot, he ought to govern his disciples with a twofold doctrine; that is, he ought first to show them all virtue and sanctity more by deeds than by words: hence, to such as are intelligent, he may declare the commandments of God by words; but to the hard-hearted, and to those of the ruder sort, he must make these precepts manifest by his actions and by his life. Therefore the Abbot ought to teach, ordain, or command nothing but what is conformable to the commands of our Lord; but let his commands and doctrine be mingled in the minds of his disciples with the leaven of divine justice. Let there be no distinction of persons in the Monastery. Let not one be loved or favoured more than another, except he be found to surpass the rest in good works and in obedience. Therefore, let the Abbot bear equal love to all; and let all be subject to the same orders and discipline, according to their deserts. With the more virtuous and intelligent, let him for the first or second time use words of admonition; but the stubborn, the hard-hearted, the proud and the disobedient, even in the very beginning of their sin, let him chastise with stripes and bodily punishment, knowing that it is written: The fool is not corrected with words." And again: "Strike thy son with the rod, and thou shalt deliver his soul from death."</p>$new_page;

<p align='center'><font size='32'> 《论院长的职责》 </font></p> <br/><p align='left'> 所以，不论谁接受院长的职位，该用两种教导去管理他的弟子，就是用言语和行动作一切圣善的示范，而行动尤胜于言语：于是，对待聪明的弟子，他需用言语阐明天主的诫命；对待心硬愚昧的弟子，他则需用行为的表率，申述天主的戒律。所以，院长的教诲、委任以及诫命，都要遵循上帝的诫命；作为天国秩序的人间代理，要使他的诫命与信条烙印在每个信徒的心里。不可偏爱隐修院中的任何人，不可厚此薄彼，除非他所行善功和听命的美德优越，被人爱戴。故此，院长必须公平地仁爱所有人；以统一的标准与纪律要求所有人，而惩罚却可以因人而异。那些宅心正直而又明智的，只有言语矫正他们一两次就够了；那些刚愎的，硬心的，傲慢的，不听命的，在初次犯过时，就用鞭打体罚惩治之，正如圣经说：“愚蠢的人不会因言语而改过”。又说：“用棍杖打你的儿子，你就救他的灵魂免于死亡”。 </p>$new_page;

<p align='center'><font size='25'>Bouquet</font></p> <br/><p align='left'>Breezes waft through princely woods, <br/>A maiden hurries to the stream<br/>To draw water in an iron-hooped pail.<br/> <br/>To the girl a bouquet floats, <br/>A fragrant bouquet of violets and roses. <br/>And when she reaches for the bouquet, <br/>She falls, alas, in the water cold. <br/> <br/>“If I only knew, bouquet so fair, <br/>Who sowed you in the fertile soil, <br/>I’d give a golden ring to him. <br/> <br/>If I only knew, bouquet so fair, <br/>Who bound you with a silky stem, <br/>I would give him the very pin from my hair. <br/> <br/>If I only knew, bouquet so fair, <br/>Who dropped you in the water cold, <br/>I would give him the wreath from my head.” </p>$new_page;

<p align='center'><font size='25'> 花束 </font></p> <br/><p align='left'>微风拂过肃穆的森林， <br/>女孩赶去溪流 <br/>用铁箍桶打水。 <br/> <br/>一束花向女孩漂来， <br/>散着紫罗兰和玫瑰的芳香。 <br/>当她向那花束伸出手去， <br/>她跌落进了，唉，那冰冷的水中。 <br/> <br/>“如果我知道，美丽的花束， <br/>是谁将你用富饶的土壤栽培， <br/>我会赠予他一只金戒指。 <br/> <br/>如果我知道，美丽的花束， <br/>是谁将你用丝绸绑起， <br/>我会赠予他我的发簪。 <br/> <br/>如果我知道，美丽的花束， <br/>是谁将你放逐于这冰冷的水中， <br/>我会赠予他我头上的花环。” </p>$new_page;

<p align='center'><font size='25'>Abandoned</font></p> <br/><p align='left'>Ah, you forest, forest dark,<br/>You forest of Miletin!<br/>How is it you alone are green<br/>In winter as in summer? <br/> <br/>I would fain not weep, <br/>Nor grieve my heart, <br/>But tell me true, good people, <br/>Who would not cry thus?<br/> <br/>Where is my father, dear father? <br/>He is lying in his grave.<br/>Where is my mother, good mother? <br/>The grass it grows above her.<br/> <br/>I’ve no brother, I’ve no sister, <br/>Young men took them from me. </p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'> 遗弃之人 </font></p> <br/><p align='left'>啊，这森林，这漆黑的森林， <br/>米勒丁的森林！ <br/>为何只有你常披青绿 <br/>无论冬夏？ <br/> <br/>我无意哭泣， <br/>更不愿感伤， <br/>但是告诉我，苍生， <br/>如何才能忍住泪水？ <br/> <br/>我的父亲身在何处，亲爱的父亲？ <br/>他早已入土。<br/>我的母亲身在何处，亲爱的母亲？ <br/>她早已为荒草掩埋。 <br/> <br/>我没有兄弟，也没有姐妹。 <br/>战争已将他们从我身边夺去。 </p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'>On Saint Wilgefortis</font></p> <br/><p align='left'> Wilgefortis, or in the Bohemian tongue, Saint Starosta, was a girl and saint who lived in the land of Portugal at the very end of Rome’s greatness and witnessed great movements of the peoples and the great strife and unrest that the entire continent faced from the barbarian pagans, particularly from the Huns, Goths, and Avars. Starosta was a virtuous girl and did live in love of Christ, but her father, a nobleman, wished to married her to the chief of a pagan tribe in order to gain more land and to please the raiders. The wretched girl, wishing to avoid this unwanted union, began to pray and she prayed to God and to all the saints for so long that she grew a thick beard, the type which old men have, which thus prevented the wedding from occurring. The barbarian chieftan, having seen his would-be bride and her beard, one that not even he would be ashamed of, withdrew from the marriage. But her father was infuriated that the wedding had been called off and he had his daughter crucified, for this all transpired in times when Christians were still persecuted. Starosta, also known as Wilgefortis from a corruption of the Latin virgo (that is, virgin) and fortis (that is, strong), who became the patron saint and protector of all that have been unjustly condemned, never achieved as much fame as other saints. But nonetheless, several statues and paintings that do portray this bearded virgin on a cross can be found. </p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'> 《圣威尔福斯》 </font></p> <br/><p align='left'> 威尔福斯，在波西米亚被称为圣斯塔罗斯塔，是生活在伟大的罗马帝国末端的葡萄牙的女圣人，目睹了人类的灾难，以及整片欧洲大陆受到的来自蛮族异教徒，特别是匈奴人，哥特人和阿瓦尔人的侵扰及动荡。 斯塔罗斯塔是一个贤惠的女孩，狂热爱戴基督，但是她的父亲，一个贵族，希望她嫁给一个异教部落的首领，取悦敌人，以获得更多的土地。为了避免这场罪恶的联姻，这个可怜的女孩开始祷告，向上帝和所有的圣徒祈祷了很久很久，以至于长出了一个老的浓密胡须，从而阻止了这场联姻。蛮族的首领，看到了他的新娘和胡须，这个不知廉耻的人决定取消婚姻。但是，她的父亲却对婚礼取消一事怒不可遏，将他的女儿钉死在十字架上，因为这一切都是在基督徒受迫害的时候发生的。斯塔罗斯塔也被称为Wilgefortis（威尔福斯），由拉丁文virgo（处女）和fortis（强者）组成，成为所有受到不公待遇之人的守护神和保护者，却从未像其他圣人那样有名望。尽管如此，仍然有雕像和绘画描绘这个有胡须的神圣处女。 </p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'>The Legend of St. Dorothy</font></p> <br/><p align='left'>Beautiful young Dorothy <br/>Lived a life of piety. <br/>Dorothy, a maiden fair, <br/>a wreath of gold upon her hair. <br/> <br/>Of gold and whitest lily <br/>Of the Virgin Mary. <br/>The King desired Dorothy, <br/>And wrote to her ardently: <br/> <br/>Fair Dorothy, wilt Thou be mine? <br/>The world shall honour beauty Thine. <br/>- It is another that I love, <br/>Our Lord Jesus Christ above. <br/> <br/>The King grew angry at Dorothy, <br/>Put her under lock and key <br/>And then to war he rode away. <br/>For seven years he fought abroad <br/>And in the eighth year he returned. <br/>Of Dorothy he then enquired, <br/>If she lived, or she had died. <br/> <br/>Oh, she lives, Sir, she lives yet, <br/>though nothing has she drunk or ate. <br/>Dorothy they brought her in, <br/>And made her stand before the King. <br/> <br/>Fair Dorothy, wilt Thou be mine? <br/>The world shall honour beauty Thine. <br/>- It is another that I love, <br/>Our Lord Jesus Christ above. <br/> <br/>The angry King gave orders then <br/>To burn her in a hot oven. <br/>The more she baked in it though, <br/>The fairer did she grow. <br/>And so they took her out again, <br/>And made her stand before the King. <br/> <br/>Fair Dorothy wilt Thou be mine? <br/>The world shall honour beauty Thine. <br/>- It is another that I love, <br/>Our Lord Jesus Christ above. <br/> <br/>The King bade them heat up oil, <br/>And put Dorothy in it to boil. <br/>The longer they boiled her though, <br/>The fairer did she grow. <br/>And so they took her out again, <br/>And made her stand before the King. <br/> <br/>Dorothy, Thou wilt be mine! <br/>The world shall honour beauty Thine. <br/>- It is another that I love, <br/>Our Lord Jesus Christ above. <br/> <br/>The King, when Dorothy had spoken,<br/>Put her on a wheel to be broken. <br/>To God almighty she appealed <br/>To save her from the torture wheel. <br/> <br/>God took mercy on Dorothy <br/>And sent a bolt from the clear blue sky <br/>That shook the earth with its great thunder <br/>And smashed the torture wheel asunder. <br/> <br/>When the King of this he heard, <br/>He had Dorothy put to the sword. <br/>Taken beyond the city wall <br/>To behead her, once and for all. <br/> <br/>Elijah she met on the way, <br/>Who asked: Where goest Thou, Dorothy? <br/>To the garden of Christ I go, <br/>To pick the fruit that in it grows. <br/> <br/>Lilies, too, I’ll pick therein <br/>Side by side with the Blessed Virgin. <br/>If so, he said, I beg of Thee, <br/>Wilt Thou please send some to me? <br/> <br/>The executioner’s sword on the first stroke, <br/>Hit her neck and in twain it broke, <br/>To the wonder of the folk. <br/>Enraged, the executioner swore, <br/>Raised his sword and struck once more. <br/> <br/>Her sacred head from her neck was cloven, <br/>And her soul departed to Heaven. <br/>To dwell amongst the angels on high <br/>Like a star in the night-time sky. <br/> <br/>Down from Heaven comes a child, <br/>A most beautiful infant mild, <br/>In its hand a basket it carries,<br/>Filled with wondrous fruit and berries. <br/> <br/>Elijah, faithful friend, <br/>This basket of fruit I bring <br/>From the orchard heavenly <br/>As Thy sister promised Thee, <br/>The day that death set her free.</p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'>The Legend of St. Dorothy</font></p> <br/><p align='left'>Beautiful young Dorothy <br/>Lived a life of piety. <br/>Dorothy, a maiden fair, <br/>a wreath of gold upon her hair. <br/> <br/>Of gold and whitest lily <br/>Of the Virgin Mary. <br/>The King desired Dorothy, <br/>And wrote to her ardently: <br/> <br/>Fair Dorothy, wilt Thou be mine? <br/>The world shall honour beauty Thine. <br/>- It is another that I love, <br/>Our Lord Jesus Christ above. <br/> <br/>The King grew angry at Dorothy, <br/>Put her under lock and key <br/>And then to war he rode away. <br/>For seven years he fought abroad <br/>And in the eighth year he returned. <br/>Of Dorothy he then enquired, <br/>If she lived, or she had died. <br/> <br/>Oh, she lives, Sir, she lives yet, <br/>though nothing has she drunk or ate. <br/>Dorothy they brought her in, <br/>And made her stand before the King. <br/> <br/>Fair Dorothy, wilt Thou be mine? <br/>The world shall honour beauty Thine. <br/>- It is another that I love, <br/>Our Lord Jesus Christ above. <br/> <br/>The angry King gave orders then <br/>To burn her in a hot oven. <br/>The more she baked in it though, <br/>The fairer did she grow. <br/>And so they took her out again, <br/>And made her stand before the King. <br/> <br/>Fair Dorothy wilt Thou be mine? <br/>The world shall honour beauty Thine. <br/>- It is another that I love, <br/>Our Lord Jesus Christ above. <br/> <br/>The King bade them heat up oil, <br/>And put Dorothy in it to boil. <br/>The longer they boiled her though, <br/>The fairer did she grow. <br/>And so they took her out again, <br/>And made her stand before the King. <br/> <br/>Dorothy, Thou wilt be mine! <br/>The world shall honour beauty Thine. <br/>- It is another that I love, <br/>Our Lord Jesus Christ above. <br/> <br/>The King, when Dorothy had spoken,<br/>Put her on a wheel to be broken. <br/>To God almighty she appealed <br/>To save her from the torture wheel. <br/> <br/>God took mercy on Dorothy <br/>And sent a bolt from the clear blue sky <br/>That shook the earth with its great thunder <br/>And smashed the torture wheel asunder. <br/> <br/>When the King of this he heard, <br/>He had Dorothy put to the sword. <br/>Taken beyond the city wall <br/>To behead her, once and for all. <br/> <br/>Elijah she met on the way, <br/>Who asked: Where goest Thou, Dorothy? <br/>To the garden of Christ I go, <br/>To pick the fruit that in it grows. <br/> <br/>Lilies, too, I’ll pick therein <br/>Side by side with the Blessed Virgin. <br/>If so, he said, I beg of Thee, <br/>Wilt Thou please send some to me? <br/> <br/>The executioner’s sword on the first stroke, <br/>Hit her neck and in twain it broke, <br/>To the wonder of the folk. <br/>Enraged, the executioner swore, <br/>Raised his sword and struck once more. <br/> <br/>Her sacred head from her neck was cloven, <br/>And her soul departed to Heaven. <br/>To dwell amongst the angels on high <br/>Like a star in the night-time sky. <br/> <br/>Down from Heaven comes a child, <br/>A most beautiful infant mild, <br/>In its hand a basket it carries,<br/>Filled with wondrous fruit and berries. <br/> <br/>Elijah, faithful friend, <br/>This basket of fruit I bring <br/>From the orchard heavenly <br/>As Thy sister promised Thee, <br/>The day that death set her free.</p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'>The Czech Campaign in Lombardy I</font></p> <br/><p align='left'>The mighty Emperor Frederick, known as Barbarossa, decided to invade the country of Lombardy, for the elders and burghers there were ignoring the Imperial charter, dishonouring it and disregarding Imperial power. And also because the treacherous Vlachs wanted to agree a pact with the Pope against the Emperor and to usurp his power. <br/> <br/>Knowing well the courage and skill of the Bohemian warriors, the Emperor asked the Czech Prince Vladislav of the House of Přemysl for the support of his troops in the campaign. In return for his aid, the Emperor let the Bohemian Prince be crowned and issue a royal edict, so that the Czechs would have a king of their own. So the Emperor did in January of the year MCLVIII. <br/> <br/>In the year thereafter the Emperor and his forces marched on Lombardy to bring order to the country and especially to humble the rich and glorious City of Milan, where the greatest insurrection was underway. Here, too, the Czech were of great help, bravely fighting the Vlachs wherever they encountered them. They built a bridge across the River Adda where the Milanese had torn down the old bridge to halt the Emperor’s advance. The Czechs held off the Lombardian troops, so that the Emperor and his army could cross the river and besiege the town. And so it came about that in the month of August the city was besieged and the Czechs were given the task of guarding the Gate of St. Dionysius. <br/> <br/>For a month the Imperial army laid siege, engaging more than once with the Milanese, and every time, the Czechs fought bravely and powerfully, for which they subsequently earned great recognition from both the Imperial soldiers and the Milanese. The Czechs thought up all manner of ruses and tricks to frighten the enemy, such as making life-size figurines of bread dough, which within sight of the battlements they roasted on a fire and ate, to spread fear among the Milanese that they ate children. Or blackening their faces with charcoal and fighting wildly, so the enemy would think it was not men, but devils who were attacking them. But it is also said that the Czechs shot poisoned arrows at the foe and all manner of other unrighteous deeds.</p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'> 捷克于伦巴底之役 I </font></p> <br/><p align='left'>强大的国王腓特烈，人称“红胡子”（或巴巴罗萨），决心征服伦巴底国，因为那里的长老与市民忽视帝国法令，亵渎它，并且不尊重帝国权威。也因为大逆不道的瓦拉几人妄图与教皇联合造反，篡夺皇位。 <br/> <br/>深知波西米亚勇士骁勇善战，皇帝向普莱米索家族的捷克君主瓦拉迪斯拉夫征求士兵，以支持他的征服计划。为了回馈他的支援，皇帝颁布了圣旨，加冕波西米亚君主为王，这样捷克人就拥有了自己的过往。其时公元1158年一月。 <br/> <br/>在之后的一年里，皇帝率领他的大军进发伦巴底，意在征服这个王国，尤其是要平定繁荣昌盛，却孕育着最顽固的反抗势力的米兰城。在那里，捷克勇士使皇帝如虎添翼，在每一次遭遇战中，英勇地与瓦拉几人血战到底。他们在阿达河上建了一座桥，因为米兰人拆毁了之前的旧桥，妄图阻挡皇帝的进攻。捷克勇士击退了伦巴底大军，以确保皇帝和他的军队能顺利过河，包围城镇。在八月的时候，城市被团团围住，捷克勇士奉命把手圣尼修之门。 <br/> <br/>皇家军队围攻了一个月之久，每次与米兰人交锋，捷克勇士都会给对手当头一棒，因此他们赢得了皇家士兵与米兰人双方的赞誉。捷克勇士想出了多种策略来击溃对手的心理防线，比如说烤出来等身大的面包，在敌人的视线里大张旗鼓地点火吃起来，让米兰人恐惧地以为他们是在生吃孩童。或是用木炭将他们的脸染成黑色的，在战场上群魔乱舞，让对手以为他们不是人，而是魔鬼在围攻他们。但也有传言宣称，捷克士兵向敌人放毒箭，还做了其他诸多违反道德的行径。 </p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'>The Czech Campaign in Lombardy II</font></p> <br/><p align='left'>The Czech King Vladislav killed the Milanese standard-bearer with his own hands. The Milanese, seeing that the fight against the Emperor and the Czechs was futile, appealed to King Vladislav to intercede on their behalf with the Emperor and to help find a peaceful solution. This was done, and the Milanese succumbed to the Emperor, recognised his authority and pad a large ransom, for which the Emperor left them many rights and confirmed old ones. Then the Emperor again pronounced Vladislav king and the Czechs returned home crowned with much glory and wealth.<br/> <br/>Many great Czech houses of ancient origin commemorate their ancestors who fought so bravely at Milan. One was granted a golden ladder in their coat of arms for scaling the walls and being the first to surmount them. Jezsche of Pardubice and his cavalry were said to have forced their way into the town and pillaged there. When they were going back, the defenders in an effort to stop them hurried to lower the iron portcullis. Jezsche managed to flee the town, but the falling portcullis killed his horse, cutting it in two and he had to get back to the siege encampment on foot with his loot, for which he was given in his coat of arms a halved silver horse, which to this day the lords of Pardubice bear on their standards and shields. <br/> <br/>The Czech nobility have long remembered the glorious campaign and commemorate it as proof of the bravery and warfaring skill of all Czechs.</p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'> 捷克于伦巴底之役 II </font></p> <br/><p align='left'>捷克国王瓦拉迪斯拉夫亲手杀掉了米兰的旗手。米兰人看到与皇帝与捷克人的持久战已然大势已去，向瓦拉迪斯拉夫国王请求，觐见皇帝，为双方寻求和平解决的条件。双方和解了，米兰人向皇帝臣服，认同了他的权威，缴纳了一笔数目可观的赔款；而皇帝也赐予了他们不少自治权，也认同了元老的权力。荣归故里之后，皇帝赐予了瓦拉迪斯拉夫国王荣耀与财富，再次以示重赏。 <br/> <br/>后世许多伟大的捷克家族都以祖先于米兰立下的战功为荣。其中一个体现便是他们盔甲上的金梯徽章，表明他们总是第一个冲上城墙，将城墙夺下来的战士。据说，帕杜比采的杰斯舍带领他的骑兵队杀进了城镇。当他们撤退的时候，守军妄图降下吊门截断他们的退路。杰斯舍得以逃出生天，但降下的吊门却将他的马劈成了两半。这样一来，他只能徒步回到围攻营地。为此，他的铠甲上获得了一个半匹银马的徽章，到今天，帕杜比采的领主们仍在他们的旗帜与盾牌上纹有这样的徽章。 <br/> <br/>捷克贵族永远铭记那场光荣的战役，纪念它以示捷克人民的骁勇善战。 </p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'>On Tournaments</font></p> <br/><p align='left'> Tournaments, or tourneys, are a favourite entertainment of the court and sometimes are an amusement for the common people far and wide, who come to watch lords of most noble birth joust, as if in the world itself such combat was rare. However, in the tourney, unlike in true battle, causing injury is forbidden and thus weapons are blunted and arms modified as needed, but sometimes unfortunate deaths do transpire. Mounted knights armed with lances may vie with one another in attempts to dismount their opponent, or knights on foot armed in diverse manner may try to throw their opponent to the ground, and the defeated must surrender his weapon, and can buy it back only in gold.<br/> <br/> The melee is a special type of hastilude, in which great teams of knights engage in combat that seems to resemble true battle, but the dealing of fatal blows is forbidden.<br/> <br/> In the Kingdom of Bohemia, the tournament was widespread during the reign of King Wenceslas, when the hero Oger from the German lands did come to his court and bring with him this curious amusement, and alongside it great poverty to the whole land, for henceforth did lords travel in great numbers to compete in tourneys and spent great fortunes upon them and no money remained for other purposes. They took to adorning themselves and their steeds with coloured cloth to pose before their opponents, and they did cross arms more in tournaments than in real combat. Today, elder men of noble birth do recall how the Czechs were once the greatest fighters in all of the Holy Roman Empire, but when the tournament arrived their abilities they did squander, and today their displays on the true battlefield are of no merit. Forsooth, some fighters of particularly great renown are incapable of dealing a proper blow in real combat, so low have their combat skill sunk. Perhaps one day, knights will become true men again and turn away from colourful tourneys and head for the battlefield, for the merriment of the tournament is certainly even an affront to God Himself. </p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'> 《骑士比武》 </font></p> <br/><p align='left'> 骑士比武，也叫竞技，是一项时髦的贵族娱乐运动，有时也会为人民大众带来乐趣。人们会看到贵族比武，这在日常生活中是十分罕见的。但是，竞技与真实的战争不一样，不允许对选手造成伤害，因此武器是被磨钝的，盔甲也是按要求改良过的，极少的情况会出现以外的伤亡情况。提矛策马的骑士试图将对手打下马来，或者是全副武装的骑士试图将对手打倒在地，被击败的一方要将武器交给获胜的一方，之后只能花钱把武器赎回来。 <br/> <br/> 混战是一种特殊的竞技形式：模仿真实的战争，许多骑士战作一团，但仍是不允许对选手造成伤害。 <br/> <br/> 在波西米亚王国，骑士比武于瓦茨拉夫国王治下盛行，德国的奥格将这种独特的娱乐方式带到了瓦茨拉夫的宫廷中，而与此同时，也给王国带来了贫穷的折磨。领主们到处游历，参加比武竞技，将大批的钱财投在了这项娱乐活动之中，因此荒废了其他的事务，使人民饱受灾难困苦。他们尽力打扮自己，给自己的坐骑套上不同颜色的装束，在他们的对手面前显露自己的雄风，而且他们在比武竞技中的交手次数远超战场。如今，贵族长辈们经常会怀念起过去骁勇善战的捷克勇士，他们曾经是整个神圣罗马帝国最强大的骑士，而当比武竞技传入以后，他们荒废了自己的能力，现在，他们在战场上的表现更是一无是处。的确，当年最强大的骑士，如今在战场上堕落得一招一式都使不出来，他们把自己的勇武扔的一干二净。或许终有一天，骑士们会再次变成真正的英雄，不再去痴迷于花里胡哨的比武竞技，而是到战场上真刀真枪地拼杀。比武竞技的出现简直是对上帝的不敬。 </p>

<p align='center'><font size='25'>Wenceslas IV</font></p> <br/><p align='left'> He is the ruler of the Lands of Bohemia and the former king of the Roman Empire, although many evil of tongue do say he is no true king and side with his half-brother Sigismund. In the year of our Lord 1361 he was born unto Emperor Charles IV and his wife Anna of Schweidnitz, and through the right of primogeniture did inherit the throne from his father. At the young age of but two years old he was crowned King of Bohemia and at the age of but fifteen he sat upon the throne of the emperor, both actions that aroused outcry, for to crown a new king whilst an older one is still alive is neither ordinary nor common and, all the same, the young king cannot rule until he reaches adulthood.<br/> <br/> When later King and Emperor Charles died and Wenceslas rightfully sat upon both thrones, he ruled well at first, but poor councillors and unwise rulers of the lands of Europe did vex him greatly, and thus the king, abandoning his initial enthusiasm, turned his attention instead to drinking and hunting. And thus in the empire did discontent with the new ruler grow, and Wenceslas, instead of reconciling conflicts, fled from them, for he did not need to resolve them. And thus it came to be that he did not go to receive his crown, for he desired not to enrage the French, who at that time had their own Pope in Avignon, and he did cause such indignation in the Margraviate of Moravia that Jobst of Moravia had him imprisoned, until the king resolved the troubles in his country. But in place of resolving conflicts Wenceslas’s disregard for proper rule persevered and he was freed by his brother John. Discontent grew and many other noblemen did protest and a League of Lords was formed to remove Wenceslas from the throne and on it they would have preferred to see sit his second brother, Sigismund, who ruled in Hungary at the time. Wenceslas heeded neither warning nor threats of the Lords and continued to rule as he saw fit, or rather to devote himself to amusements, and when the Lords had no more patience for him and a rebellion against him broke out, he requested the assistance of his second brother, Sigismund, to whom he entrusted rule of the land.
